Final point - there‚Äôs plenty of evidence to show imposter syndrome can be harmful. It means you may work twice as hard to prove your competence and credibility to yourself and others. This can lead to burnout and poor mental health.

PS. I agree imposter syndrome is not always bad - it can encourage humility. BUT, important to recognise who‚Äôs more affected (women, minoritised groups) & how it holds people back. It can lead to the silencing of minoritised voices from public discourse, which is bad for everyone

I've been tagged in conversations about imposter syndrome on medical twitter in the last few weeks - thank you for these.

Here's my take on it - a @BMJLeader blog I wrote a couple of years ago. I'm currently writing more, which I hope I can share soon!

https://t.co/Q0u4QWTGLc

Finally, the lack of media representation impacts on the diversity of role models visible. It may put people off from applying for those roles if as @chrischirp says it implies that "this is not meant for me" 

https://t.co/rXXIDO4OSu

Also, if you are not seen as being credible in your role, because you don't fit the expectation of what society expects (regardless of competency) then you have to work harder to prove yourself - leads to imposter phenomenon and burnout.
Here‚Äôs just 2 examples of untitling during media coverage of COVID-19 https://t.co/SYPXm8qHvr

The same with untitling & uncredentialing which we have seen play out in the media when reporting on COVID.

The omission of women & PoC in *that* Times article is disgraceful & has wide ranging implications. If the public don‚Äôt see women & PoC as experts in the media, they may not be deemed to be credible in their roles irl. And then we end up needing hashtags like #ILookLikeASurgeon

By Susan Sontag https://t.co/0fB04bT7hd

‚Äúto comprehend ‚Äòradical‚Äô or ‚Äòabsolute‚Äô evil, we search for adequate metaphors. But the modern disease metaphors are all cheap shots. The people who have the real disease are also hardly helped by hearing their disease‚Äôs name constantly being dropped as the epitome of evil.‚ÄùSontag

‚ÄúAnd there is an increasing tendency to call any situation one disapproves of a disease. Disease, which could be considered as much a part of nature as is health, became the synonym of whatever was ‚Äòunnatural.‚Äô‚Äù Sontag

‚ÄúPunitive notions of disease have a long history.Nothing is more punitive than to give a disease a meaning‚Äìthat meaning being invariably a moralistic one. Any important disease whose causality is murky,& for which treatment is ineffectual,tends to be awash in significance‚Äù Sontag

Maladies of Empire - such a fascinating history which reveals the roots of infectious disease epidemiology. 

Of particular interest for me, the chapters on:

Florence Nightingale as a statistician 

The horrifying use of enslaved infants to produce ‚Äúsmall pox vaccine matter‚Äù

/5

‚ÄúThe use of numbers, which purported to be an objective, apolitical practice, became a central force in public health‚Äù.

And @ohdearindira & I, members of @SAHAR_hiv & doctors @NHSBartsHealth talked about HIV now - how treatment & care have advanced over the years, the benefits of getting tested, U=U, & HIV prevention tools - PrEP & PEP.

@KakaiyaMina & @Sham_WRcH, members of @SAHAR_hiv gave moving & inspirational accounts, stressing the need to address HIV stigma, the importance of peer support & mental health support for people living with HIV. https://t.co/PktDnz6sIy

https://t.co/9UuxtGz3SO
